Author: Mylo#8306
Content: https://komodoplatform.com/tt2019-18-public-blockchain-as-a-service-pbaas/

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: Re miketout building on kmd

Author: artik123#2884
Content:
If we take the linux example, is it definitely not a good use for a average joe PC user. windows is much suitable. 
I might say that it is most useful for a technical guys using it as a hobby, 
other target audience would be companies that develop embedded software or some other linux derivatives. 


I've scattered around the examples you gave, and they were good sources! of komodo potential customers...
1. developers that don't have large dev teams and also wish to save a lot of time (miketout example)
2. developers that care about freedom and don't like to be taxed. (things you also mentioned)
3. ?

(mentioning developers twice might suggest that it is a primary a B2B infrastructure platform? meaning that the primary customers are businesses/developers?
and they will create B2C products?)


the reason that I mentioned the bitcoin generator, is that for some people, a zero cost blockchain generator 
(especially PoS chains. with PoW he still needs komodo's security) with very basic parameters, 
that would probably appear in the future for every major project, will make the cut for some people. 
this and a multi million mature ecosystem that he could take advantage of.

I understand that komodo is on a different level. 
I'm just trying to have a clear view of the trade-offs of someone standing at this critical decision point.
and I think that people here should also have a clear view of that, so they could address it in the best way possible.


Moreover, every project/company should first have their own understanding their own dna.

Based on your own story with Nxt which led to the creation of this project, I think that the branding should be based around the word 'freedom'
freedom to create, freedom to use, freedom from taxes etc...
first thing that has to come in mind when someone thinks about komodo is the word 'freedom'.

Author: artik123#2884
Content:
Secondly, I think that story telling is extremely important. 
people live and die on stories. many people still remember the story of microsoft, apple etc.
you could have a story of how we got here ( the lost of millions... and the breakout from Nxt it makes a good story... also help him to understand why he shouldn't use or be under the policies of others...) tailored by a branding story teller.
(let me give you some examples... the anonymous story of satoshi nakamoto 
(and the media attention it got based on his mysterious anonymity, for every project it worth its weight in gold..., 
silly wow story of dogecoin, silver vs gold story of litecoin etc... last 2 would be worthless without the story)

Author: artik123#2884
Content:
In geo politics the things that have led to a very successful countries are:
AAA people, good education system and both political and economical inclusive institutions. open and merit based society.
if you have these properties, the chances of success are huge.
in komodo terms the first 2 would primary mean, I think, top developers and good tutorials of everything both for developers and users or even to have an academy.
all in one place. step by step. categorized with video walkthroughs starting from beginners all the way up to creating a new cc module.


But at the end, ~200 countries are like ~200 experiments of competing values...

Why shouldn't komodo have a constitution? 
to be written what komodo's most adhere to, stands for, and what komodo core values are? the things that it will or will never do.
the things that it could guarantee forever to any new blockchain on the platform.

Maybe this could be the analogy:

life - security
liberty - freedom to control his own destiny
property rights - his own native coin

All to make it a more an easy to understand, and more cohesive project.

Author: Mylo#8306

Last years website had freedom to .... freedom to .... freedom to .... with a video.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: It is a multi-headed dragon.  The ecosystem is developing more approachable tech.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: these are not tech issues, i will stay out of it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if it isnt a tech issue, there is no deterministic solution and it can be debated, literally forever and usually end up with two or more sides, totally convinced they are correct.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there are not obvious compiler or linker errors to fix

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no algorithms to deal with

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: non-deterministic

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: others are tasked to deal with such issues, I do tech, that can be shown to work without debates

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just one question about end users and linux. how many android phones are there? none of those phones are used by any end users, is your position?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: osx is also arguably a close relative to linux, so apple products are not used by any end users either?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i think you are totally underestimating the pervasiveness of linux

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and yes, I know there are many forks of linux that are not linux anymore, but my point is that without linux in the first place, they wouldnt exist

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: oh, and a large number of websites running linux, i guess those are all just hobbyists

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so we have a total disagreement about some fundamental things and if your position is that linux is just for hobbyists or embedded software companies, then it seems for you komodo can only be for a very small number of people, but to me I know komodo will allow crypto to be used by the masses. But the gap is too big when your position is that linux is just for hobbyists

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: like i said, non-deterministic as shown by how you can believe linux cannot get end users

Author: Hegelian#0018
Content: Which version of linux do you think is the best?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is no single best version, it all depends on what exactly you need most. the important thing is that regardless of what it is, odds are very good that there is an open source solution that is close to your problem

Author: artik123#2884
Content:
No one thinks that there is a problem with the tech. the tech is light years a head of any other project.
but since you are founder of this project, you have the overall responsibility, oversight and success of the project. even if you're a tech guy!
and thats why this project is biased towards the tech. (if you were a product guy it would be probably biased towards the product etc.). it's doesn't necessarily a bad thing, it's just the way it is. end result, for each type of founder, there would be a different resource allocations.


Regarding the two sides of the debate, I disagree. would someone be convinced/argue that this project is not about freedom?


I think that there is a misunderstanding here...  why do you think that I'm trying to underestimate the project?
I think it has a huge potential. otherwise I wouldn't be here in the first place...
I just think that at the moment it doesn't get its right place and recognition.

Android is probably used by billion people, but what I said is that they are not the main customers of the creator of linux. same for intel
I specifically mentioned embedded software companies or some other linux derivatives (like andorid...).

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i dont know why you have this idea that it is a company that I am running. i am on the open source side of things and deal with all the code issues. that is enough work to do

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I cant appear in public, so I very well cant be the public spokesperson

Author: artik123#2884
Content: "i dont know why you have this idea that it is a company that I am running" - what happens if you leave?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is why I want things to be less centralized around me and have avoided anything non-technical as much as possible. If I left, there wouldnt be any changes at all outside the open source side of things. and for that we know have devs that are familiar with pretty much the entire codebase

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: certainly i could do things more efficiently in some cases, but nothing that existing devs couldnt figure out on their own if needed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i dont participate in team meetings

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i am not involved, so they are certainly not dependent on me

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I do have control over the last million KMD from the ICO, but that wont be lasting for much more than a year, the BTC is managed by the ICO escrows and I have never even signed the multisig, even though I am a signer

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in the last months I have shifted to training other devs to do CC and have started writing the blog to explain things in plain english

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: I cant sustain 16 hours x 7 days per week for more than 5 years at a time. i need to reduce hours to recharge

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i dont do anything about the build system, websites, etc. even the notary network others are advancing it, not me

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: my value is really being overestimated.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in virtually every area now (even CC) for implementations and debugging, there is a dev that I usually go to in order to get the best result. I have been working to make myself obsolete for many years and finally it is becoming close. now that others can debug, isolate and fix problems and also code from scratch new ideas, overall productivity is going up a lot

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i can just come up with some crazy ideas now and again and others can make it real, so even if i reduce my hours to only 40hrs per week, i think the overall tech output will increase and its not like the marketing side has been able to keep up with the old level of production

Author: artik123#2884
Content: I think that it's a positive change

Content:
the time that it becomes a system and not company marketcap will follow.
